{"comments": {"id": 255, "count": 175, "talk_id": 282}, "threadId": 255, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "282", "description": "Nine days before TED2008, filmmaker David Hoffman lost almost everything he owned in a fire that destroyed his home, office and 30 years of passionate collecting. He looks back at a life that's been wiped clean in an instant -- and looks forward.", "event": "TED2008", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "David Hoffman: What happens when you lose everything", "slug": "david_hoffman_on_losing_everything", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "218", "slug": "david_hoffman", "is_published": true, "firstname": "David", "lastname": "Hoffman", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Filmmaker", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/36880_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "I have often tried to understand how David does what he does. After observation, it becomes glaringly simple. He listens! I mean; he really listens, to people and situations.", "whotheyare": "In David Hoffman's long film career, he's made documentaries on everything from Amelia Earhardt to B.B. King, from double-dutch jump-roping to F-15 fighter pilots. Lately he's been fascinated with the early space program and our mania for all things Sputnik.", "whylisten": "

\t\t\tDocumentary filmmaker David Hoffman has been capturing reality for almost 4 decades, following his wide-ranging interests and turning them into films for PBS, The Discovery Channel, A&E, National Geographic. Highlights from his career include the groundbreaking experimental doc King, Murray, which blurred boundaries between truth and fiction as it tracks its subject through a debauched weekend in Las Vegas; A Day With Filmmaker Timmy Page, about a 12-year-old auteur; and his series of films on American indigenous music.

Lately, he has become fascinated with the Atomic-era Space Race, turning out a feature-length documentary about the Sputnik era. Sputnik Mania was scored by Thomas Dolby and has played at festivals and theaters around the country.

Hoffman suffered a devastating setback in early 2008 when, nine days before TED2008, his home, containing a vast archive from his long and fascinating career, burnt to the ground. His next project: to reframe his life and rebuild.

"speakers": [{"id": "218", "slug": "david_hoffman", "is_published": true, "firstname": "David", "lastname": "Hoffman", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Filmmaker", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/36880_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "I have often tried to understand how David does what he does. After observation, it becomes glaringly simple. He listens! I mean; he really listens, to people and situations.", "whotheyare": "In David Hoffman's long film career, he's made documentaries on everything from Amelia Earhardt to B.B. King, from double-dutch jump-roping to F-15 fighter pilots. Lately he's been fascinated with the early space program and our mania for all things Sputnik.", "whylisten": "

\t\t\tDocumentary filmmaker David Hoffman has been capturing reality for almost 4 decades, following his wide-ranging interests and turning them into films for PBS, The Discovery Channel, A&E, National Geographic. Highlights from his career include the groundbreaking experimental doc King, Murray, which blurred boundaries between truth and fiction as it tracks its subject through a debauched weekend in Las Vegas; A Day With Filmmaker Timmy Page, about a 12-year-old auteur; and his series of films on American indigenous music.

Lately, he has become fascinated with the Atomic-era Space Race, turning out a feature-length documentary about the Sputnik era. Sputnik Mania was scored by Thomas Dolby and has played at festivals and theaters around the country.

Hoffman suffered a devastating setback in early 2008 when, nine days before TED2008, his home, containing a vast archive from his long and fascinating career, burnt to the ground. His next project: to reframe his life and rebuild.

"}], "speaker_name": "David Hoffman", "tags": ["culture", "film", "library", "personal growth", "storytelling", "movies"], "title": "What happens when you lose everything", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1075671}]}
author: David_Hoffman;
title: What happens when you lose everything

aws-transcripts.transcript: I had a fire nine days ago. My archive, 175 films, My 16 millimeter negative, all my books and my dad's books. My photographs I had collected I was a collector major big time. It's gone. I just looked at it and I didn't know what to do. I mean, this was was I My things always live in the present. I love the present. I cherish the future. I was taught some strange thing is a kid like you got to make something good out of something bad? You got to make something good out of something bad. This was bad, man. I was I I cough. I was sick. That's my camera lens. The 1st 1 the one I shot my Bob Dylan film with 35 years ago. That's my feature film. King Murray. One con film festival in 1970. The only print I had That's my papers. I was in minutes, 20 minutes. Epiphany hit me. Something hit me. You got to make something good out of something bad. I started toe say to my friends, Neighbors, my sister. By the way, that Sputnik I ran it last year. Sputnik was downtown the negative. It wasn't touched. These are some pieces of things I used in my Sputnik feature film, which opens in New York in two weeks. Uh, downtown I called my sister. I called my neighbors. They said, Come dig, That's me at my desk. Uh, I was a death. Took 40 years to build, You know, all the stuff. That's my daughter, Jeanne. She came. She's a nurse in San Francisco. Dig it up, I said, Pieces. I want pieces, bits and pieces. I came up with this idea, a life of bits and pieces, which I'm just starting to work on my next project. That's my sister. She took care of pictures because I was a big collector of just snapshot photography that I believed said a lot of those are some of the pictures that something was good about the burned pictures. I didn't know I looked at that and said, Wow, is that better than? That's my proposal on Jimmy Doolittle. I made that movie for television. It's only copy. I had pieces of it idea about women, so I started to say, Hey, man, you are too much. You could cry about this. I really didn't I instead said, I'm gonna make something out of it and maybe next year. And I appreciate this moment to come up on this stage with so many people, have already given me so much solace and just say the testers, I'm proud of me that I take something bad, I turn it, and I'm gonna make something good out of this. All these pieces that's awful. Leipzig's original photograph I loved I was a big record collector. Records didn't make it. Boy, I tell you, Film burns film burns. I mean, this was 16 millimeter safety film. Ah, the negatives are gone. Has my father's letter to me telling me toe, uh, marry the woman I first married when I was 20. Um, it's my daughter and me, She's still there, she said this morning. Actually, that's my house. My family is living in the Hilton Hotel in Scotts Valley as my wife, Heidi, who didn't take it as well as I didn't my children, Davey and Henry, my son Davey, in the hotel two nights ago. So my message to you folks from my three minutes is that I I appreciate the chance to share this with you. I will be back. I love being a Ted. I came to live it and I am living it.
